pullRequest.body:
This PR adds the types and lemmas for oracle-based computation. In this model, computations are run on a monad which also counts the number of oracle queries executed. With it, it becomes possible to reason about the upper bound of the query complexity of algorithms. In the future, we could extend this work to include the necessary bits from information theory and probability to also reason about lower bounds on query complexity, like the work in https://github.com/girving/debate.

Zulip discussion: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/144837-PR-reviews/topic/.2318629.20runtime.20complexity.20of.20sorting.20a.20list

Co-authored-by: Geoffrey Irving <irving@naml.us>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: messageFile.md

Hi @eric-wieser and @girving 
I updated the PR according to Eric's suggestion of letting the comp monad query over arbitrary dependent types. If I understand correctly, this is the only change that is going to be done for now, correct?
@tomaz1502, please take another look at my suggestion above. - your types are not as dependant as mine were, and in particular all your oracles are forced to take the same types as input.
please_merge_master.md

> @tomaz1502, please take another look at my suggestion above. - your types are not as dependant as mine were, and in particular all your oracles are forced to take the same types as input.

Thanks, you're right. I updated it, but now I don't think we can easily define `value'`, that is, a function that takes a single oracle and runs the computation with it - the function that ignores the input index and always return the same oracle can't be typed, since the domain of the oracle depends on the index. Maybe it is okay to remove this function? (and also `cost'`)

It's definitely possible to define them, but you'll need to specialize the index types too.

I'm not sure we want them in this PR though; let's leave them out and add them when we need them.
I pushed a commit showing how to get the primed versions.

### PR summary [f7ebc35ea7](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20924/commits/f7ebc35ea71cfebc01f43cf2fbd0328e2a174da1)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Computability.QueryComplexity.Defs` (new file)|216|
| `Mathlib.Computability.QueryComplexity.Basic` (new file)|220|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ BOracle`
`+ Comp`
`+ Oracle`
`+ allow`
`+ allowAll`
`+ allow_pure`
`+ bind'`
`+ cost`
`+ cost'`
`+ cost_allow`
`+ cost_bind`
`+ cost_map`
`+ cost_pure`
`+ cost_query`
`+ cost_query'`
`+ instance : LawfulMonad (Comp ι ω s) := LawfulMonad.mk'`
`+ instance : Monad (Comp ι ω s)`
`+ pure'_eq`
`+ pure_bind`
`+ query`
`+ query'_bind`
`+ query'_eq`
`+ run`
`+ run_pure`
`+ run_query`
`+ run_query'`
`+ value`
`+ value'`
`+ value_allow`
`+ value_bind`
`+ value_map`
`+ value_pure`
`+ value_query`
`+ value_query'`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>Increase in tech debt: (relative, absolute) = (1.00, 0.01)</summary>

|Current number|Change|Type|
|-:|:-:|:-|
|110|1|disabled simpNF lints|

Current commit [f7ebc35ea7](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/f7ebc35ea71cfebc01f43cf2fbd0328e2a174da1)
Reference commit [d19a965eea](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/commit/d19a965eea3da6363f3fc9b4bc64a2050ffdf8e1)

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

> I pushed a commit showing how to get the primed versions.

Oh, I see now. Thanks!

I hope the barrage of commits didn't feel like me treading on your toes; some of the suggestions I had were devoid of any deesign content (like replacing `if` with `Pi.single`), and would have been much more painful for both of us if I'd typed them out in detail and then you'd gone through and fixed all the breakages!

I got some significant simplifications out of replacing the two `Comp` arguments here with `Bool → Comp`. It practice it seems to reduce the number of cases needed in proofs.

See recent https://github.com/girving/debate for the new style.
No need for parentheses here.
Per previous comment, using `Bool → Comp` in the definition of `query'` replaces the if with `(f x).run os`, which is cleaner.
Just "after execution" ("it's" is both wrong and unnecessary).
(f.run o).1
(f.run o).2 i
No need for parentheses around `o i y` (but also this if will go away once you do the `Bool → Comp` thing).
"doesn't"
Extra space after f.
I think this one should be `simp` too.
Unnecessary parentheses around `f b`.
And also around `(fun b => ...)`.
Unnecessary parentheses around the fun.
Unless there are obstructions to doing so, `Type*` would probably be a good idea throughout

What do you think of something much more dependently-typed, like this?
```lean
/-- `Comp α β s γ` is the type of `γ`-producing computations that have access to a family of `oracles i : (a : α i) → β a` restricted by `i ∈ s`. -/
inductive Comp {I : Type*} (α : I → Type*) (β : {i : I} → α i → Type*) (s : Set I) (γ : Type*) : Type _ where
  /-- A pure value without an oracle computation. -/
  | pure : γ → Comp α β s γ
  /-- An invocation of the permitted oracle `o` with input `a`, and a way to proceed with computation for each possible return value. -/
  | query (o : I) (ho : o ∈ s) (a : α o) : (β a → Comp α β s γ) → Comp α β s γ

/-- A sorting computation has access to an oracle that can decide the relation between two elements. -/
abbrev SortingComp {α} (r : α → α → Prop) := Comp (fun _ : Unit => α × α) (fun ab => Decidable (r ab.1 ab.2))
```

This has two main benefits over your version:
* It lets us have oracles that decide non-binary decisions
* It gives the continuation access to a proof that the decision was correct.
I agree that making the output flexible is good! I’ll make this change to my https://github.com/girving/debate version as well.

It's also not clear to me whether we need a family of oracles, or if a single oracle would suffice; after all, you can have an oracle that takes a sigma type and uses `.fst` to decide which suboracle to call.

This makes `cost` slightly more complicated, but if the cost were configurable per-query, rather than a constant `1`, I think you can still encode the same things.

My version of `Comp` now has an arbitrary, dependent output type: https://github.com/girving/debate/commit/5a3d62f7e85f026d3756013c5a28cb6d68e07e8c.

Was all fairly straightforward, and actually made some of the proofs *cleaner* since it forced genericity.

Great! I note you stuck with `Bool` in the specialization. I'd be curious to know if the `Decidable` refactor was unreasonably painful. I think it's fine to get the sorting stuff in mathlib with the general `Comp` instantiated with a `Bool` specialization, but in the longer term I could foresee algorithms which need a proof from the oracle in order to produce their results, and so it would be great to have some idea of what pain that creates.

What do you mean by sticking with Bool?

If you mean for debate itself, leaving Bool requires introducing Wasserstein distance on Prob or some similar metric. It would be a significant refactor, and I’m not even clear exactly which generalization would be best.
I mean as opposed to switching to some `Decidable P` for some `P`, to specify exactly what it is that the oracles are deciding

Aha, as in: now that oracles can return any type, make them return Decidable for e.g., Sort? My guess is that this won’t work, as you want lower bound theorems to go through even if you assume Classical.
Yes, I've now concluded the same. If the return type is constrained enough to encode what was decided, then most likely you've given it the information it needs to shortcut the oracle!

Here's a case that maybe justifies the dependent output in the example above: if you have a sorting oracle, you perhaps can't safely get hold of a proof that the result is sorted, but you might want a proof that the output is a permutation of the input.

It's not entirely clear to me what purpose `s` serves in `Comp` (which is the reason for these existing); as far as I can tell, the sorting stuff does not need it.

@girving, do you have an example in mind where this is useful, vs just changing the indexing type of `I` if a different set of oracles is wanted?

Here’s how it’s used in the debate protocol: https://github.com/girving/debate/blob/d3e2d0bb7f6f450bb3899fb349a69133329541eb/Debate/Protocol.lean#L94

And without it, this theorem and similar wouldn’t be true, as an evil Bob could query Alice’s oracle: https://github.com/girving/debate/blob/d3e2d0bb7f6f450bb3899fb349a69133329541eb/Debate/Cost.lean#L55

I should say I’m sympathetic to the worry that this is too specific to one kind of formalized result. We don’t need it for sort, so stripping it would be fine if we just want to get sort into mathlib (my lower bound on sort doesn’t use this either, of course).

The alternative I'm proposing in that example is for Bob, Alice, and Vera to have different indexing types. So for instance, your `def step` would have indexing type `BobUnit ⨁ AliceUnit ⨁ VeraUnit`.

Of course, this then becomes tricky to plumb combining together the oracles...

Ah, interesting. So the set argument to
Comp goes away, and cost takes a set of queries to count across.
My guess is that doing it with just types ends up messier, at least if you want to do variety of subsets. But I’m not confident about this.
I'm happy to stick with the sets for now.
I had a play around with a set-free version in #22194

```suggestion
    (z, c + Pi.single i 1)
```
Though using `DFinsupp` here would be slightly nicer because then you get a computable `Repr` for free

I think `DFinsupp` would be less ergonomic in practice, since it's harder to write down functions then.

Unfortunately I think a meta-lesson here is that the needs of the particular `debate` formalisation diverge from the maximally general version of `Comp`. E.g., I started doing the dependent output stuff, and it'll be fine mostly, but then all my applications will be `Bool` for fundamental reasons: the theorems depend on the number of bits in the representation of the output type, and it's cleaner if the number of bits is one.

On the margin that argues against trying to upstream it at this point, especially if the only standard (non-debate) result is sorting.
In light of https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20924#discussion_r1929625674, are you in favor of the generality again?
(I also think it's fine to not use DFinsupp for now)
Yep, output generality seems very good: it turned out to be easy to migrate to.
@tomaz1502, note the code suggestion above is independent of the radio of the discussion.
I took the liberty of applying this, and also adding `DecidableEq` because it seems convenient for computations to actually be computable.
Usually it's a bad idea to have two ways of spelling things. Can you add a simp lemma that `pure' = pure` to `Defs.lean`, and then remove all the `pure'` theorems from this file?
If you make this an `abbrev`, then you can delete all the duplicate theorems about `allowAll`, as the ones about `allow` will automatically apply!
This isn't true; it doesn't determine which _oracle_ to run, but rather which _continuation_ `Comp` to run. It might choose to end the computation with `pure`, in which case no oracle is run at all!

I think you should write this the other way around, as
```suggestion
@[simp]
lemma pure'_eq (a : α) : (pure' : α → Comp ι ω s α) = pure := rfl
```
I've recorded some of my hesitations with this design here. I think we can safely get all of the mergeSort PRs reviewed and merged, and then revisit these decisions.

pullRequest.title: feat(Computability/QueryComplexity): Oracle-based computation

nodes.body: messageFile.md

source.title: feat(Computability/QueryComplexity/Sort.lean): Formalization of upper bound of queries for merge sort

source.title: Allow each oracle to take a different input type
